alabi.core module¶

core.py¶

class alabi.core.SurrogateModel(fn=None, bounds=None, labels=None, prior_sampler=None, cache=True, savedir='results/', model_name='surrogate_model', verbose=True, ncore=16, scale=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class used to estimate approximate Bayesian posterior distributions or perform Bayesian optimization using a Gaussian process surrogate model

Parameters:

  • fn – (function, required) Python function which takes input array theta and returns output array y=fn(theta). For bayesian inference problems fn would be your log-likelihood function.

  • bounds – (array, required) Prior bounds. List of min and max values for each dimension of theta. Example: bounds = [(0,1), (2,3), ...]

  • labels – (array, optional)

  • cache – (bool, optional)

  • savedir – (str, optional)

  • savedir – (str, optional)

  • model_name – (str, optional)

  • verbose – (bool, optional)

  • ncore – (int, optional)

  • scale –

    (str, optional) Method for scaling training sample y. Options:

    • None - no scaling

    • ’standard’ - normalize by standard deviation

    • ’log’ - log scale

    • ’nlog’ - log negative scale (for probability distributions logP -> log(-logP)

active_train(niter=100, algorithm='bape', gp_opt_freq=10, save_progress=False, opt_init=False, obj_opt_method='nelder-mead')[source]¶
Parameters:

  • niter – (int, optional)

  • algorithm – (str, optional)

  • gp_opt_freq – (int, optional)

  • save_progress – (bool, optional)

evaluate(theta_xs)[source]¶

Evaluate predictive mean of the GP at point theta_xs

Parameters:

theta_xs – (array, required) Point to evaluate GP mean at.

Returns ypred:

(float) GP mean evaluated at theta_xs.

find_map(theta0=None, lnprior=None, method='nelder-mead', nRestarts=15, options=None)[source]¶
find_next_point(nopt=3, opt_init=False)[source]¶

Find next set of (theta, y) training points by maximizing the active learning utility function.

Parameters:

nopt – (int, optional) Number of times to restart the objective function optimization. Defaults to 1. Increase to avoid converging to local maxima.

fit_gp(theta=None, y=None)[source]¶
init_gp(kernel=None, fit_amp=True, fit_mean=True, fit_white_noise=False, white_noise=-12, gp_scale_rng=20, overwrite=False, gp_opt_method='powell', gp_nopt=3)[source]¶

Initialize the Gaussian Process with specified kernel.

Parameters:

kernel –

(str/george kernel obj, optional) george kernel object. Defaults to “ExpSquaredKernel”. See https://george.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/kernels/ for more details. Options:

'Kernel', 'Sum', 'Product', 'ConstantKernel', 'CosineKernel', 'DotProductKernel', 'EmptyKernel', 'ExpKernel', 'ExpSine2Kernel', 'ExpSquaredKernel', 'LinearKernel', 'LocalGaussianKernel', 'Matern32Kernel', 'Matern52Kernel', 'MyLocalGaussianKernel', 'PolynomialKernel', 'RationalQuadraticKernel'

init_samples(train_file=None, test_file=None, reload=False, ntrain=None, ntest=None, sampler=None)[source]¶

Draw set of initial training samples and test samples. To load cached samples from a numpy zip file from a previous run, you can specify the file using train_file or test_file. Otherwise to run new samples, you can specify the number of training and test samples using ntrain and ntest.

Parameters:

  • train_file – (str, optional) Path to cached training samples. E.g. train_file='results/initial_training_sample.npz'

  • test_file – (str, optional) Path to cached training samples. E.g. test_file='results/initial_test_sample.npz'

  • reload – (bool, optional) Attempt to load cached samples from default cache files? Will not be used if user specifies train_file or test_file. Defaults to False.

  • ntrain – (int, optional) Number of training samples to compute.

  • ntest – (int, optional) Number of test samples to compute.

  • sampler – (function, optional) Prior function for drawing training samples. Defaults to uniform using self.bounds

init_test(nsample=None)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • nsample – (int, optional) Number of samples. Defaults to nsample = 50 * self.ndim

  • sampler – (str, optional) Sampling method. Defaults to 'sobol'. See utility.prior_sampler for more details.

init_train(nsample=None)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • nsample – (int, optional) Number of samples. Defaults to nsample = 50 * self.ndim

  • sampler – (str, optional) Sampling method. Defaults to 'sobol'. See utility.prior_sampler for more details.

lnprob(theta)[source]¶

Log probability function used for emcee, which sums the prior with the surrogate model likelihood

\[\ln P(\theta | x) \propto \ln P(x | \theta) + \ln P(\theta)\]

where ln P(x | theta) is the surrogate likelihood function and ln P(theta) is the prior function.

Parameters:

theta – (array, required) Array of model input parameters to evaluate model probability at.

load_test(cache_file)[source]¶

plot(plots=None, save=True)[source]¶

Plot diagnostics for training sample, GP fit, MCMC, etc.

Parameters:

plots (array, required) –

List of plots to generate. Will return an exception if SurrogateModel has not run the function which creates the data used for the plot. Options:

'gp_error' 'gp_hyperparam' 'gp_timing' 'gp_train_corner' 'gp_train_iteration' 'gp_fit_2D' 'emcee_corner' 'emcee_walkers' 'dynesty_corner' 'dynesty_corner_kde' 'dynesty_traceplot' 'dynesty_runplot' 'mcmc_comparison'

run_dynesty(like_fn='surrogate', ptform=None, mode='dynamic', sampler_kwargs={}, run_kwargs={}, multi_proc=False, save_iter=None, ptform_comment=None)[source]¶

Use the dynesty nested-sampling MCMC package to sample the trained GP surrogate model. https://github.com/joshspeagle/dynesty

Parameters:

  • ptform – (function, optional) Log-prior transform function. Defaults to uniform prior using the function utility.prior_transform_uniform with bounds self.bounds.

  • sampler_kwargs – (dict, optional)

  • run_kwargs – (dict, optional)

  • multi_proc – (bool, optional)

  • ptform_comment – (str, optional)

run_emcee(like_fn='surrogate', lnprior=None, nwalkers=None, nsteps=50000, sampler_kwargs={}, run_kwargs={}, opt_init=True, multi_proc=True, lnprior_comment=None)[source]¶

Use the emcee affine-invariant MCMC package to sample the trained GP surrogate model. https://github.com/dfm/emcee

Parameters:

  • lnprior – (function, optional) Log-prior function. Defaults to uniform prior using the function utility.lnprior_uniform with bounds self.bounds.

  • nwalkers – (int, optional) Number of MCMC walkers. Defaults to self.nwalkers = 10 * self.ndim.

  • nsteps – (int, optional) Number of steps per walker. Defaults to nsteps=int(5e4).

  • sampler_kwargs – (dict, optional)

  • run_kwargs – (dict, optional)

  • opt_init – (bool, optional)

  • multi_proc – (bool, optional)

  • lnprior_comment – (str, optional)

save()[source]¶

Pickle SurrogateModel object and write summary to a text file

alabi.gp_utils module¶

gp_utils.py¶

Gaussian process utility functions for initializing GPs and optimizing their hyperparameters.

alabi.gp_utils.configure_gp(theta, y, kernel, gp_hyper_prior, fit_amp=True, fit_mean=True, fit_white_noise=False, white_noise=-12, hyperparameters=None)[source]¶
alabi.gp_utils.default_hyper_prior(p, hp_rng=20, mu=None, sigma=None, sigma_level=3)[source]¶

Default prior function for GP hyperparameters. This prior also keeps the hyperparameters within a reasonable huge range [-20, 20]. Note that george operates on the log hyperparameters, except for the mean function.

Parameters:

p – (array, required) Array of GP hyperparameters

Returns lnprior:

(float) log prior value

alabi.gp_utils.optimize_gp(gp, theta, y, gp_hyper_prior, p0, nopt=3, method='powell', options=None, bounds=None)[source]¶

alabi.mcmc_utils module¶

mcmc_utils.py¶

alabi.mcmc_utils.estimate_burnin(sampler, est_burnin=True, thin_chains=True, verbose=False)[source]¶

Estimate the integrated autocorrelation length on the MCMC chain associated with an emcee sampler object. With the integrated autocorrelation length, we can then estimate the burn-in length for the MCMC chain. This procedure follows the example outlined here: https://emcee.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorials/autocorr/

Parameters:

  • sampler – (emcee.EnsembleSampler, optional) emcee MCMC sampler object/backend handler, given a complete chain

  • est_burnin – (bool, optional) Estimate burn-in time using integrated autocorrelation time heuristic. Defaults to True. In general, we recommend users inspect the chains and calculate the burnin after the fact to ensure convergence, but this function works pretty well.

  • thin_chains – (bool, optional) Whether or not to thin chains. Useful if running long chains. Defaults to True. If true, estimates a thin cadence via int(0.5*np.min(tau)) where tau is the intergrated autocorrelation time.

  • verbose – (bool, optional) Output all the diagnostics? Defaults to False.

Returns iburn:

(int) burn-in index estimate. If est_burnin == False, returns 0.

Returns ithin:

(int) thin cadence estimate. If thin_chains == False, returns 1.

alabi.utility module¶

utility.py¶

Utility functions in terms of usefulness, e.g. minimizing GP utility functions or computing KL divergences, and the GP utility functions, e.g. the bape utility.

alabi.utility.agp_utility(theta, y, gp, bounds)[source]¶

AGP (Adaptive Gaussian Process) utility function, the entropy of the posterior distribution. This is what you maximize to find the next x under the AGP formalism. Note here we use the negative of the utility function so minimizing this is the same as maximizing the actual utility function.

\[u(x_*) = \mu(x_*) + \frac{1}{2} \ln(2\pi e \sigma(x_*)^2) + \log p\]

See Wang & Li (2017) for derivation/explaination.

Parameters:

  • x – (array, required) parameters to evaluate

  • y – (array, required) y values to condition the gp prediction on.

  • gp – (george GP object, required)

  • util – (float) utility of theta under the gp

alabi.utility.assign_utility(algorithm)[source]¶
alabi.utility.bape_utility(theta, y, gp, bounds)[source]¶

BAPE (Bayesian Active Posterior Estimation) utility function. This is what you maximize to find the next theta under the BAPE formalism. Note here we use the negative of the utility function so minimizing this is the same as maximizing the actual utility function. Also, we log the BAPE utility function as the log is monotonic so the minima are equivalent.

\[u(x_*) = e^{2\mu(x_*) + \sigma^2(x_*)} \left(e^{\sigma^2(x_*)} - 1 \right)\]

See Kandasamy et al. (2015) for derivation/explaination.

Parameters:

  • x – (array, required) parameters to evaluate

  • y – (array, required) y values to condition the gp prediction on.

  • gp – (george GP object, required)

  • util – (float) utility of theta under the gp

alabi.utility.eval_fn(fn, theta, ncore=16)[source]¶
alabi.utility.jones_utility(theta, y, gp, bounds, zeta=0.01)[source]¶

Jones utility function - Expected Improvement derived in Jones et al. (1998)

\[EI(x_*) = E(max(f(\theta) - f(\theta_{best}),0)) \]

where f(theta_best) is the best value of the function so far and theta_best is the best design point

Parameters:

  • x – (array, required) parameters to evaluate

  • y – (array, required) y values to condition the gp prediction on.

  • gp – (george GP object, required)

  • zeta – (float, optional) Exploration parameter. Larger zeta leads to more exploration. Defaults to 0.01

  • util – (float) utility of theta under the gp

alabi.utility.lnprior_normal(x, bounds, data)[source]¶
alabi.utility.lnprior_uniform(x, bounds)[source]¶
alabi.utility.minimize_objective(obj_fn, y, gp, bounds=None, nopt=1, method='nelder-mead', t0=None, ps=None, args=None, options=None, max_iter=100)[source]¶

Optimize the active learning objective function

alabi.utility.prior_sampler(bounds=None, nsample=1, sampler='uniform')[source]¶

Hypercube sampling function which draws nsample within given bounds. Wrapper around scikit-optimize sampling methods. For more info see: https://scikit-optimize.github.io/stable/auto_examples/sampler/initial-sampling-method.html

Parameters:

  • bounds – (array, required) Array of (min,max) bounds for each dimension of the prior.

  • nsample – (int, optional) Defaults to nsample=1.

  • sampler –

    (str, optional) Defaults to 'uniform'. Options:

    'uniform', 'sobol', 'lhs', 'halton', 'hammersly', 'grid'

alabi.utility.prior_sampler_normal(prior_data, bounds, nsample=1)[source]¶
alabi.utility.prior_transform_normal(x, bounds, data)[source]¶
alabi.utility.prior_transform_uniform(theta, bounds)[source]¶
